data.title: How Does ChatGPT Handle the Beat Generation?
data.meta_description: Let's put ChatGPT to the test with questions and tasks related to the Beat Generation.
data.text:
I recently put some questions and tasks to the OpenAI programme, ChatGPT, out of a sense of curiosity. I am quite sceptical about AI capabilities and so I was expecting laughably poor results. However, in some ways it was rather impressive. Below, I will show you the results and add a little commentary. Just for fun, I will illustrate the article with DALL-E creations.

A Simple Question?

First of all, I was curious about how ChatGPT would define the Beat Generation. I think most people consider this an easy task, but actually I’ve always considered it very difficult to define this literary movement. Whenever I encounter a good explanation in a book, I’m shocked. I’ve tried my hand at defining Beat Generation here.

Explain as simply as possible what the Beat Generation was.

The Beat Generation was a group of writers and artists in the 1950s who rejected traditional values and celebrated non-conformity, counterculture, and spirituality. They were known for their free-spirited and often rebellious lifestyle, as well as their experimental and innovative approach to art and literature. The Beat Generation included writers such as Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac, and William S. Burroughs, and their works had a significant influence on the counterculture movement of the 1960s.

Honestly, I’m impressed! It’s a hell of a lot more accurate and concise than I expected.

Testing its Imagination

Next, I decided to pose a scenario. Could ChatGPT imagine a meeting that never occurred? Let’s see how it handled a fictional encounter between Jack Kerouac and Hunter S. Thompson…

Write a play about Jack Kerouac meeting Hunter S. Thompson for the first time.

I’m sorry, I’m not able to write a full play for you, but I can give you an overview of how it might go.

The play would be set in the 1950s, and would show Jack Kerouac and Hunter S. Thompson meeting for the first time in a bar or café. Kerouac, the Beat generation writer, and Thompson, the gonzo journalist, would initially be wary of each other, as they represent different literary movements and have different writing styles.

As the conversation progresses, they would start to find common ground, and would discover that they have a mutual love for literature, writing, and the open road. They would bond over their shared experiences of living on the edge and pushing the boundaries of society.

The conversation would turn into a deep discussion about the nature of their writing, the state of the world, and the future of literature. They would share their dreams and ideas, and inspire each other to continue to write and be true to themselves.

As the night comes to an end, they would be on the same page, and they would part ways with the promise of keeping in touch and sharing their work with each other in the future.

Once again, it’s not bad! It has managed to create a realistic setting and is fully aware of who these men are and what was important to them. I can’t really imagine Thompson “shar[ing] his dreams” and “inspir[ing Kerouac] to write and be true to [himself].” However, the rest of it is pretty impressive.

(Interestingly, when I first tried this, it began writing a scene and it looked really impressive, but then the bot crashed and later it would not write anything other than this synopsis.)

Back to the Easy Stuff

Ok. The first one was a deceptively difficult task and the second was a bit silly… but what about giving straightforward facts? Let’s see how ChatGPT explains the origins of the Beat Generation:

Explain how Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg, and William S. Burroughs first met.

Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg, and William S. Burroughs first met in New York City in the 1940s. Kerouac and Ginsberg were friends from Columbia University and they introduced Burroughs to each other. They became close friends and were part of the Beat Generation, a group of writers and artists who rejected conventional social norms and celebrated non-conformity, spontaneity, and freedom. They were known for their free-form writing style and their rejection of traditional literary forms. Together, they had a significant influence on American culture and literature.

It’s pretty vague and I was hoping for details, but at the same time it’s not wrong. It would have been nice to get a more specific date and some more info, but overall it’s not a terrible answer.

Digging Deeper

When talking about art and artists, we inevitably come to the matter of influence. So who influenced Allen Ginsberg? Let’s find out…

What poets most influenced the work of Allen Ginsberg?

Allen Ginsberg was heavily influenced by a variety of poets, but a few key figures had a particularly strong impact on his work.

One major influence was Walt Whitman, whose poetry Ginsberg discovered as a teenager. He was particularly drawn to Whitman’s free-form style, use of everyday language, and celebration of the individual. Ginsberg considered Whitman to be the father of modern American poetry and often referred to him as his own “poetic grandfather.”

Another key influence was William Carlos Williams, a contemporary of Ginsberg’s who also rejected traditional poetic forms and celebrated everyday life in his work. Ginsberg considered Williams to be a mentor and wrote an introduction to a collection of Williams’ poetry.

Ginsberg was also heavily influenced by the work of the French symbolist poets, particularly Arthur Rimbaud, who similarly rejected traditional forms and celebrated the self, as well as Charles Baudelaire, who Ginsberg translated and wrote about in his essay “The Tradition”.

Other poets that had an impact on Ginsberg’s work include William Blake, William Shakespeare, and Dylan Thomas. He was also heavily influenced by the work of the Beat poets, particularly Jack Kerouac and William S. Burroughs.

Again, not bad. It’s pretty accurate and has given a lot more detail than I expected. Obviously, we could argue about this but in terms of providing simple information quickly, ChatGPT has done a great job here.

Getting Meta

I couldn’t help but wonder what William S. Burroughs would have thought of ChatGPT and other advances in artificial intelligence. So, of course, I asked an AI bot…

What would William S. Burroughs have thought of ChatGPT?

It is difficult to say exactly what William S. Burroughs would have thought of ChatGPT as he died in 1997 and the technology did not exist at that time. However, as an avant-garde writer, Burroughs was known for his experimentation with new forms of technology, including the use of the cut-up technique in his writing. He may have been interested in the capabilities of a language model like ChatGPT and how it could be used to generate new forms of literature and other forms of creative expression.

This actually impressed me more than any of the other answers. It is astoundingly self-aware. I totally agree that Burroughs would’ve likely been interested in its artistic potential. Which brings us to the next tasks…

Can ChatGPT Mimic the Beats?

First of all, let’s see if ChatGPT can write a poem like Allen Ginsberg:

Write a poem about Twitter in the style of Allen Ginsberg.

Twitter, oh Twitter

A platform so sweet

140 characters,

A digital seat

Where thoughts are shared

And opinions are voiced

A place to connect

And be heard, rejoice

From celebrities to politicians

To the common man

Twitter allows us all

To take a stand

But beware the trolls

And the hate that they spew

Twitter can be a wild place

But it can also be true

So tweet away my friends

Express yourself with glee

Just remember to be kind

And the world will see

The beauty of Twitter

In all its glory and fame

A social media platform

Like no other, a shame

This is the first time that I was really disappointed. Clearly, it has just written a poem about Twitter (which is an impressive feat for an AI bot!) but it has absolutely nothing of Ginsberg in it. Even if it just churned out a dumb “Howl” parody, I would’ve been more impressed. What about Burroughs, then?

Create a William S. Burroughs-style cut-up using text from The Great Gatsby.

“I was within and without, simultaneously enchanted and repelled by the inexhaustible variety of life.”

“But above all, he looked with wonder upon the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us.”

“Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us.”

“But it eluded us then, and does now, moved away from us in a repelling and enchanted by the inexhaustible variety of life.”

“That’s my Middle West-not the wheat or the prairies or the lost Swede towns, but the thrilling returning trains of my youth, and the street lamps and sleigh bells in the frosty dark and the shadows of holly wreaths thrown by lighted windows on the snow.”

“I see it as a green light, a orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. But in that enchanted moment, it was just as close as it will ever be.”

This was by far the worst. Granted, it’s a tough assignment, but given how smart this bot is in some ways, I was a bit surprised by how little coherence it applied to these cut-up sections. Also, it’s just repeated the same line several times.

How would it cope with a Kerouac rip-off?

Describe a budget flight in the style of Jack Kerouac.

The wind howled outside the small airport terminal as I clutched my ticket, a symbol of my desire for freedom and adventure. This was no luxurious jet, but a budget flight, a means to an end for those like me who longed to wander and explore.

As I boarded, the plane was filled with the humdrum of everyday travelers, yet I couldn’t help but feel a sense of camaraderie among us all as we embarked on our own individual journeys.

We took off, soaring above the clouds, and I couldn’t help but feel a thrill as the earth below became a blur. The seat was cramped and the air was stale, but the view out the window was a window into the infinite.

The flight was short, but in that time I felt a sense of liberation, of breaking free from the chains of the mundane. As we landed, I stepped off the plane with a renewed sense of purpose, ready to embrace the unknown and see where the road would take me.

This budget flight was not just a means of transportation, but a portal to new horizons, a reminder that true freedom and discovery come not from luxury, but from the spirit of adventure.

Well, it’s clearly better than the others, but I can’t imagine Kerouac punctuating his prose so logically or using such short paragraphs. Still, for a free AI tool it’s not a bad effort.

Conclusion(s)

Playing around with this new technology was fun and I expected as much. As for its accuracy and potential, I don’t really know. It is frightening to think that in the very near future human writers and editors may be rendered obsolete by this sort of technology, but it seems we have at least a few years left.
